Like the worst case scenario if you hit on some coin or degen options trade and make  $ XXmm, but use that as information that you're a genius investor, and then just start slinging stuff & blow up. Be honest w yourself, stay humble and grounded, investing is really hard.

In a fast-growing industry like crypto especially, but in general, net worth outright is less impressive as the time that wealth is kept and ideally compounded. In some aspects keeping/growing big money is a lot harder than making it, esp if you hit on some far-tail outcome.

Still generally think this statement is true, just not really worried about MSTR ironically bc of its capital structure and track record of surviving bear mkt.

Closed ibit calls on bounce, best realized pnl trade for me of the year. Obv still have core BTC spot holdings. Aping ATH break felt obvious but no strong views from here, so not gonna share every mico-decision. Still do have TLT puts on which are doing rlly good this morning.
Bitcoin crashing to one hundred twenty thousand dollars
Saylor is up $30 billion now
At $140k BTC, Satoshi would/will flip Sergey Brin to become the 10th richest person in the world. They flipped Bill Gates over the weekend and currently sit at 12.

Tbh dropping out & going all in on BTC/crypto was obviously +EV for me bc I was lucky to have the Twitter account, was rlly young, & didn't go to an incredible school, but going forward the next big bet will be less obv & higher stakes. It's easier when you have nothing to lose.

If you want to rlly make it you have to bet big on something from a time allocation perspective or capital allocation perspective. I like @splitcapital's recent tweet that w/ info so abundant, edge is now in sizing. Fewer actions, bigger bets, cut losers, let winners ride.
